Dehydrogenation of methyl glycolate (MG) is an attractive method for synthesizing methyl glyoxylate (MGO, an important high-value chemical and pharmaceutical intermediate), which is calling for a qualified catalyst. Cu/SiO2-AE catalysts were prepared via the ammonia evaporation method for the title reaction, showing the catalytic performance strongly dependent on their preparation/activation parameters as well as the reaction conditions. The preferable 15Cu/SiO2-80AE (15 wt% Cu-loading; AE-treatment at 80 °C; calcined at 500 °C) after H2-reduction at 300 °C achieved a high MG conversion of 38.5 % with MGO selectivity of 79.0 % at 400 °C. The Cu/SiO₂-AE catalyst demonstrates promising catalytic performance, achieving 38.5 % MG conversion with 79.0 % MGO selectivity at 400 °C. The Cu⁺/Cu⁰ ratio plays a crucial role in catalytic activity, as revealed by XPS, FTIR, and MG-TPSR. Deactivation mechanisms were studied, and catalyst regeneration was explored, offering insights for industrial application in green MGO synthesis. Graphical Abstract Keywords Methyl glycolate Methyl glyoxylate Dehydrogenation Cu catalyst Ammonia evaporation method Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Methyl glyoxylate (MGO), an archetype of α-oxocarboxylates due to its simplest structural complexity, has become a significant role within the realms of chemical production and pharmaceutical synthesis [1,2]. In recent years, there has an ever-increasing demand for the MGO in application for efficient and effective synthesis of various high value-added chemicals, such as glyoxylic acid, cyclandelate, and Quinalphos MGO, which leads to a significant gap in the supply [3]. Hence, it is particularly desirable to render an efficient, low-cost and environmental-friendly method for the mass production of MGO. Traditional production of MGO is primarily constrained by the selection of raw materials and synthesis methods. Conventional MGO synthesis via selective oxidation of α-unsaturated carboxylates (e.g., acrylates) necessitates toxic oxidants (e.g., nitric acid, periodate, ozone, hydrogen peroxide) and produces hazardous waste [4–7]. In contrast, methyl glycolate (MG), in principle, can be efficiently converted to MGO through a straightforward dehydrogenation process. Specially, the MG can be synthesized via selective hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) [8], carbonylation-hydrolysis of acetaldehyde [9], and other methods [10–12]. Research on catalysts and industrial development have reached a mature stage, making MG a readily available and cost-effective raw material for the MGO synthesis. The dehydrogenation of alcohol molecules can be divided into two types: oxidative dehydrogenation and catalytic dehydrogenation. Recently, Wang et al. [13] made progress on the oxidative dehydrogenation of methyl glycolate (MG) to produce MGO over a hydroxyl-deficient α‑Fe2O3 catalyst using the O2 molecule, achieving a high intrinsic activity of 0.26 gMG gcat −1 h−1. The suggested dehydrogenation pathway obviates the requirement for stoichiometric oxidants, thus reducing wastewater production compared to the existing methods. However, the highly unsaturated nature of the MG molecule results in a significant tendency to over-oxidation, even achieving a CO2 selectivity of 8 % under the most favorable conditions [13]. This significantly diminishes the atomic economy of the MG-to-MGO process, conflicting with the principles of green chemistry and today's carbon neutrality targets [14,15]. Consequently, the catalytic dehydrogenation of MG stands out as a more promising approach for the synthesis of MGO, but is urgently calling for a qualified catalyst. Catalysts for gas-phase alcohol dehydrogenation can be classified into two categories: those comprising noble metals and those comprising transition metals. The noble catalysts (e.g., Pd, Ru, Rh, Ag, Au) exhibited exemplary performance in alcohol dehydrogenation, yet their high cost represents a considerable obstacle to their broader implementation [16–21]. The copper-based catalysts have gained considerable acceptance in the conversion of alcohols to their corresponding aldehydes, due to their exceptional ability to cleave O−H and C−H bonds while remaining inert towards C−C bond dissociation [22–25]. Wang et al. [26] synthesized highly dispersed Cu/γ-Al2O3 catalysts via the initial wetness impregnation method for the dehydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), resulting in 69.8 % conversion of HMF and 44.9 % yield of DFF at 130 °C. Luo et al. [27] developed a Cu/Al@SBA-15 catalyst with high CuO dispersion and small particle size through a bimetallic synergistic effect, enabling the efficient dehydrogenation coupling of o-aminophenol and benzyl alcohol to produce benzothiazoles with yield up to 99 % at 110 °C. Zhang et al. [28] synthesized a hierarchical echinus-like Cu-MFI-AE catalyst for the catalytic dehydrogenation of ethanol, being capable of converting 97 % ethanol into acetaldehyde with 93 % selectivity while showing good activity/selectivity maintenance throughout 500 h test at 250 °C using a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 0.53 h−1. Jiang et al. [29] used a complexation-impregnation method to prepare an active and stable silica-encapsulated nano Cu catalyst (Cu@SiO2/SiO2) for the gas-phase dehydrogenation of 1,6-hexanediol (1,6-HDO) to ε-caprolactone (ε-CL), which achieves 95.3 % 1,6-HDO conversion with 80 % ε-CL selectivity and is stable for at least 100 h. Xiao et al. [30] synthesized a Cu/SiO2 catalyst with plentiful Cu0/Cu+ interfaces via the hydrolysis-precipitation method for potential use in the direct dehydrogenation of ethyl lactate to ethyl pyruvate, showing that the intrinsic activity of such catalyst is almost linearly increased with the Cu0/Cu+ interface length. With regard to the catalytic dehydrogenation mechanism of the Cu-base catalysts, a minority viewpoint posits that the activity for the catalytic dehydrogenation of alcohols is commensurate with the proportion of the monophase copper [31,32]. The prevailing view is that the synergistic effect between the Cu+ and Cu0 species significantly enhances the catalytic activity for the dehydrogenation of alcohols. Specifically, Cu+ plays a key role in absorbing alcohol and weakening O−H to facilitate its cleavage while dissociating the α-C−H with the aid of Cu0 to produce CO [28,33,34]; the H atoms formed in the aforementioned steps will migrate to Cu0 via spillover and subsequently bonds together to H2 [35–37]. Such new insights on the synergistic catalytic mechanism of copper-based catalysts for the alcohol dehydrogenation shed a light on design and tailoring of a highly effective dehydrogenation catalyst. The ammonia evaporation (AE) method yields Cu/SiO₂ catalysts with an optimized Cu⁺/Cu⁰ ratio [38]. This method has been successfully commercialized for the hydrogenation of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) to ethylene glycol (EG), making it a promising candidate for MGO synthesis. In the light of this, it seems prudent to investigate the potential of employing a Cu-based catalyst of the kind described in the title reaction. To accomplish this goal, a series of Cu/SiO2 catalysts were synthesized by the ammonia evaporation method with varied Cu-loading and AE temperature and examined in the dehydrogenation of MG to MGO reaction. The resulting catalysts showed catalytic performance strongly dependent on their preparation/activation parameters as well as the reaction conditions. The catalysts were carefully characterized by means such as X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), infrared spectroscopy for MG adsorption-desorption, and temperature-programmed surface reaction with MG (MG-TPSR), to gain insight into the mechanism of Cu+/Cu0 involved synergistic catalysis in the MG dehydrogenation to MGO reaction. The Cu+ sites were responsible for the adsorption/activation of MG and the Cu0 sites facilitated the hydrogen formation, while an optimal Cu+/Cu0 ratio was a guarantee for the Cu+ and Cu0 working in a highly synergistic manner. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Materials The Cu(NO3)3·3 H2O (99 wt% purity) and 25–28 wt% ammonia solution were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The SiO2 was purchased from Aldrich Co., Ltd. All chemicals were directly used as received without further treatment. 2.1.2 Catalyst synthesis The Cu/SiO2 catalysts were synthesized by the ammonia evaporation method [28]. Taking the synthesis of catalysts with 15 % copper loading as an example, Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O of 1.877 g was dissolved into 50 mL deionized water, followed by adjusting the solution pH to 11 by dropwise adding 25–28 wt% ammonia solution under vigorous stirring. After that, SiO2 of 2 g was added into the as-obtained copper ammonia solution at room temperature while holding stirring for 30 min. The resulting suspension underwent ammonia evaporation under stirring at 70, 80, and 90 °C. The evaporation process was terminated until the pH reached 6–7. The mixture was then filtered and washed three times with deionized water. The filter cake was dried overnight at 120 °C and calcined in air at 500 °C for 4 h to obtained the catalyst product. As-synthesized catalysts were denoted as 15Cu/SiO2-xAE, where x represents the evaporation temperature and AE stands for the ammonia evaporation. For comparison, a 15Cu/SiO2-IWI catalyst with Cu loading of 15 wt% was prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) method, followed by drying overnight at 120 °C and calcining in air at 500 °C for 4 h. The rationale behind the utilization of the IWI method for the preparation of a contrastive catalyst is attributable to two key factors: its simplicity and its cost-effectiveness in industrial contexts. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer (Japan) from 10 to 80° at a 2θ scanning speed of 10° min−1, using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.542 nm) generated at 30 kV and 25 mA. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements were carried out on a BELSORP-MAX gas adsorption analyzer at −196 °C to determine the specific surface area (SSA) and porosity of the prepared catalysts. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100F, Japan) was used to investigate the morphological and nano-structural features of the catalysts. Inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) was performed for quantitative determination of the Cu loading in the catalysts on a Thermo IRIS Intrepid IIXSP ICP spectrometer (USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) were used to characterize the valence state of surface Cu species in catalysts. Both the XPS and Auger spectra were acquired on an AXIS SUPRA spectrometer (Kratos Analytical Inc.) with monochromatic Al Kα radiation at 1486.69 eV (300 W), using an analyzer pass energy of 40.0 eV. The binding energies were calibrated by C 1 s core level of the contaminated carbon at 284.8 eV. Prior to the XPS analyses, all samples were pre-treated with H2 gas flow at 300 °C for 1 h in the pretreatment chamber connected with the XPS chamber. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and MG-temperature programmed surface reaction (MG-TPSR) were all conducted on a TP 5080 adsorption/desorption instrument (Xianquan Industrial and Trading Co. Ltd., China) equiped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and an online mass spectrometer (Proline Dycor, AMETEK Process Instrument, USA). The H2-TPR profiles were acquired using the TCD by heating the fresh catalyst sample (0.1 g) in a 10 % H2/N2 carrier gas (30 mL min−1) from 25 to 500 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. For the MG-TPSR, the catalyst sample was firstly reduced in a H2 flow (30 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h (if not specified) and then cooled down to 20 °C. The resulting sample was then transferred into a round-bottom flask that had been thoroughly purged with argon and filled with 5 mL of MG. After soaking the catalyst in the MG liquid, the sample was evacuated at 60 °C for 1 h to ensure the thorough removal of any excess MG, including that physically adsorbed on the sample surface. Such sample of 0.1 g was taken and packed into the quartz tube reactor of the TP 5080 adsorption/desorption instrument, followed by purging for 1 h with He. Finally, the MG-TPSR was carried out in a He flow (30 mL min−1) from 20 to 450 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 while the effluents were detected by the on-line MS spectrometer to monitor the dehydrogenation of pre-adsorbed MG on the catalyst surface against the temperature. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments on MG adsorption-desorption were conducted on a Nicolet Nexus 670 spectrometer (USA), equipped with a mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector and a high temperature transmission cell rigged with CaF2 windows. The catalysts diluted in KBr (catalyst/KBr mass ratio was 1:1) were pressed to be a wafer, placed into the cell chamber, reduced with H2 (30 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 1 h, and cooled down to 25 °C in a N2 flow while taking a reference spectrum. For the MG adsorption, a N2 flow saturated with MG vapor by bubbling method at room temperature was introduced into the cell chamber to pass through the catalyst wafer for 30 min, followed by purging for 30 min with N2 to remove the gaseous MG. After that, the FT-IR spectra were acquired continuously to capture the dynamic change of the MG molecule pre-adsorbed on the catalyst wafer with rising temperature from 25 to 400 °C. This was accomplished by collecting 64 scans per spectrum at a resolution of 4 cm−1. Carbon deposition on the spent catalyst was measured by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) on a Rigaku Thermo plus Evo TG 8120 instrument. Briefly, the spent catalyst sample (10 mg) was heated from 25 to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 in an air flow (30 mL min−1). 2.3 Catalyst evaluation Anaerobic catalytic dehydrogenation of MG was performed in an electrically heated fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor (8 mm i.d.,700 mm length) at 340–400 °C, using a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 1.0 gMG gcat −1 h−1. The mixture of 0.4 g Cu/SiO2-xAE catalyst (100–125 μm) and 0.4 g quartz sand (100–125 μm) was loaded into the reactor and kept in place by placing quartz wool at both ends. Before the catalytic evaluation, the catalyst was reduced with H2 at 300 °C for 1 h. The MG, together with a N2 flow controlled by a mass flow controller, was introduced into the reactor via a peristaltic pump (Fire Track, 102S/R, USA). The liquid effluent captured by a cold trap (5 °C) was analyzed using a Shimadzu 2014 C gas chromatograph fitted with a 30 m HP-INNO-Wax capillary column (DIMKA) and a flame ionization detector (FID). Given the fact that no carbon-containing gaseous products were detected in the off-gas from the reactor, the MG conversion and product distribution were calculated based on the equations defined as follows: (1) Conversion MG ( % ) = n MG , 0 − ∑ n MG − i ( i = MGO , GA , MMOA , DMDG ) n MG , 0 × 100 % (2) Selectivity i ( i = MGO , GA , MMOA , DMDG ) ( % ) = n MG − i ∑ n MG − i × 100 % where n MG,0 is molar amount of intake MG, n MG-i is molar amount of MG converted into i (i = MGO (Methyl glyoxylate), GA (glycolic acid), MMOA (Methyl Methoxyacetate), or DMDG (Dimethyl Diglycolate)). The reaction rate was calculated based on the following equation: (3) Reaction rate ( mol MGO g Cu − 1 h − 1 ) = WHSV × Conversion MG × Selectivity MGO n MGO , 0 * Cu loading Regenerability of the spent catalysts was also investigated. In brief, the spent catalysts were calcined in air at 500 °C for 1 h and subsequently reduced with H2 at 300 °C for 1 h. The regenerated catalysts were examined in the title reaction under identical reaction conditions. 2.4 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations Considering the lack of thermodynamic parameters (i.e., standard enthalpies of formation (H0), standard entropy ( S m θ ), etc.) of the MG and MGO molecules, a simple quantum chemistry calculation was conducted for a preliminary understanding of the thermodynamic equilibrium of the dehydrogenation of MG to MGO reaction. The structures of MG and MGO molecules (Fig. S1) were built in Gaussian View 5.0 and the calculations were conducted employing the Gaussian 16 program package [39], including a structure optimization and frequency calculation using B3LYP method and 6–31 G* basis [40], as well as a zero point energy calculation using CCSD(T) method. The fundamental thermodynamic parameters were analyzed by the Shermo code [41] to obtain the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) and MG equilibrium conversion. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 DFT calculation of thermodynamic equilibrium As shown in Fig. 1, the anaerobic catalytic dehydrogenation of MG to MGO is thermodynamically unfavorable when considered in the context of the positive ΔG. The ΔG decreases linearly with rising the temperature, in association with an obvious increase of the MG equilibrium conversion, indicating that this reaction becomes favorable at elevated temperatures. However, undesirable side reactions such as pyrolysis and condensation will tend to occur if implementing the reaction at excessively high temperatures. Therefore, a qualified catalyst for this reaction should be active and selective at relatively low temperatures. 3.2 Catalytic performance Indeed, pyrolysis of the reagent and products became unacceptably serious at or over 420 °C (not shown). In the present work, therefore, the catalyst evaluation was carried out at temperature in range from 340 to 400 °C using the representative 15Cu/SiO2-80AE (15 wt% Cu loading; AE treatment at 80 °C; calcined at 500 °C) and Cu/SiO2-IWI for comparison. In Fig. 2a, the reaction results for their catalytic dehydrogenation of MG are plotted against the reaction temperature. As can be seen, the contrastive Cu/SiO2-IWI catalyst was completely inert for this reaction in the whole temperature range studied. In contrast, over our Cu/SiO2-80AE catalyst the MG conversion and MGO yield showed almost a linearly upward trend with rising temperature from 340 to 400 °C. Moreover, the effect of reaction temperature was studied on the product distribution resulting from the MG dehydrogenation catalyzed by the 15Cu/SiO2-80AE (Fig. 2b). The MGO selectivity was increased progressively from 57.3 % to 79.0 % with rising temperature from 340 to 400 °C in association with the increase in the MG conversion from 14.2 % to 38.5 %. Undesirable byproducts were also inevitably yielded, including methyl methoxyacetate (MMOA), dimethyl diglycolate (DMDG), and glycolic acid (GA). The possible side reaction pathways were summarized in Fig. S2. The MMOA and DMDG are from the etherification reaction on the acidic sites [42], GA is a hydrolysis product [43], and glycolide (GC) is a self-condensation product of MG [44]. As shown in Fig. 2b, the GA formation was markedly suppressed (selectivity declined from 31.3 % to 7.0 %) with rising temperature from 340 to 400 °C whereas the MMOA and DMDG formation was oppositely increased slightly. Fig. 3 shows the effects of the preparation/activation parameters of Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts on their performance for the catalytic dehydrogenation of MG to MGO. The MG conversion and MGO selectivity both showed a volcano-shaped evolution against the AE temperature (x, from 70 to 100 °C), Cu-loading (from 7.5 wt% to 30 wt%), calcination temperature (from 300 to 600 °C), and H2-reduction temperature (from 200 to 400 °C). The MG conversion and MGO selectivity achieved top over the 15Cu/SiO2-80AE catalyst with a Cu-loading of 15 wt%, which was obtained after AE-treating at 80 °C, calcining at 500 °C, and subsequently reducing with H2 at 300 °C. The catalyst preparation parameters lower or higher than the optimal values (i.e., 15 wt% Cu-loading, AE-temperature of 80 °C, calcination temperature of 500 °C, and reduction temperature of 300 °C) made the catalysts favorable for the formation of byproducts (Fig. 3), because of the negative impacts such as difficult reduction, decreased Cu dispersion, and unsuitable Cu+/Cu0 ratio (to see posterior sections). As well known, the Cu/SiO2 synthesized by AE method is characteristic of the copper phyllosilicate (Cu2Si2O5(OH)2, a copper silicate with lamellar structure). In combining this information with the fact that the Cu/SiO2-IWI was inactive for the catalytic dehydrogenation of MG to MGO (Fig. 2), it is reasonably safe to say that the copper phyllosilicate played a vital role in deriving highly active sites for this reaction. Among the catalyst preparation/activation parameters studied, the formation of copper phyllosilicate was governed by the AE temperature. Therefore, the further exploration herein was focused on the structural and chemical origin of AE temperature (x) dependent catalytic performance of the 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts. 3.3 Structural and textural properties Fig. 4a shows the XRD patterns of fresh 15Cu/SiO2-xAE (x = 70, 80, 90) and 15Cu/SiO2-IWI catalysts. The 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts all exhibited broad and weak peaks at 2θ of 30.8°, 35.0°, 57.5° and 62.4°, being assigned to the copper phyllosilicate (JCPDS #27–0188). In contrast, very strong CuO diffraction peaks (JCPDS #48–1548) were detected for the 15Cu/SiO2-IWI. A broad peak of amorphous silica was detected at 2θ of about 21.2° on all catalysts. Moreover, irregular needle-like structures in the TEM images of the 15Cu/SiO2-xAE, being indicative of formation of the copper phyllosilicate (Fig. S3) [38]. Fig. 4b shows the FT-IR spectra of the 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts, in which the characteristic band assigned to the vibrational mode of O−H bonds (δO−H) in the copper phyllosilicate was detected at 670 cm−1 [45,46] in association with two broad bands at 1100 cm−1 and 800 cm−1 for the asymmetric and symmetric stretching of Si−O bonds in SiO2. According to the report by Toupance et al. [45], the relative amount of copper phyllosilicates in the Cu/SiO2 can be measured by calculating the ratio of the intensity of the δO−H band at 670 cm−1 to that of the νSi−O band at 800 cm−1 (I 670/I 800). In Fig. 4c, the I 670/I 800 was plotted against the 15Cu/SiO2-xAE and 15Cu/SiO2-IWI catalysts, showing that rising the AE-temperature in range studied was conducive to the formation of copper phyllosilicate while no copper phyllosilicate was presented in the 15Cu/SiO2-IWI. The textural properties were measured by nitrogen adsorption/desorption, with the results shown in Fig. 4d and Table S1. As can be seen, our 15Cu/SiO2-xAE all showed high S BET (419–433 m2 g−1) and similar type IV nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops at P/P0 = 0.6–1.0, indicating the presence of agglomerates of plate-like particles thereby leading to formation of slit-shaped mesopores with BJH pore size of ∼25 nm (inset in Fig. 4d). However, the 15Cu/SiO2-IWI with a S BET of 189 m2 g−1 also showed type IV nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms with H3-type hysteresis loops at P/P0 = 0.8–1.0 and large BJH pore size of over 100 nm (Fig. S4; Table S1). 3.4 Reducibility and surface Cu+/Cu0 pair As previously noted, the formation of copper phyllosilicate enhances the interaction between copper ions and SiO2 support, facilitating the selective reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ [47,48]. The coexistence of Cu0 and Cu+ in the catalyst is considered to be a synergistic catalytic active site for hydrogenation and dehydrogenation reactions [28,33–37]. Thus, the reduction behavior of our 15Cu/SiO2-xAE was investigated by using H2-TPR as well as the 15Cu/SiO2-IWI for comparison, with the results shown in Fig. 5. In the H2-TPR profile for each 15Cu/SiO2-xAE sample, a large H2 consumption peak was observed at below 200 °C in association with a very small peak centered at ∼240 °C, being assigned to the stepwise reduction (Cu2+→Cu+→Cu0) of the copper phyllosilicate (Fig. 4a-c) and some other copper oxide such as bulk CuO, respectively. The contrastive 15Cu/SiO2-IWI showed a single H2 consumption peak centered at 206 °C, being assigned to the CuO dispersed on the SiO2 [47]. Notably, a split evolution of the H2 consumption peak was observed for the reduction of copper phyllosilicate in the 15Cu/SiO2-xAE (Fig. 5). The extent of peak splitting was observed to reach its maximum when the AE temperature (x) was increased from 70 to 80 °C. However, a further increase of 10 °C in the AE temperature resulted in a reduction in the degree of peak splitting. The above observation indicated that the further reduction of Cu+ species to Cu0 became relatively difficult in case of the 15Cu/SiO2-80AE in comparison with the 15Cu/SiO2-70AE and -90AE samples. Thus, the Cu+ species in the 15Cu/SiO2-80AE is more stable. The TEM images of the 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts after H2-reduction at 300 °C are illustrated in Fig. 6, showing that the Cu particles were sized at ∼4 nm (being consistent to that from XRD measurement, Table S2). By comparison, the Cu particles seemed to be dispersed on the SiO2 more uniformly for the 15Cu/SiO2-80AE. In addition, the 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts showed quite similar textural properties (S BET: 284–290 m2 g−1, V p: 0.60–0.71 cm3 g−1; Table S2). In contrast, the reduced 15Cu/SiO2-IWI catalyst was featured by a large Cu particle size of ∼15 nm and a small S BET of 167 m2 g−1 but a large V p of 0.91 cm3 g−1 (Table S2). The chemical state of surface Cu species for the reduced 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts was analyzed by XPS/AES spectroscopy, with the results shown in Fig. 7. On the surfaces of all three reduced 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts, two clear peaks at binding energy (B.E.) of 932.9 eV (Cu 2p3/2) and 952.6 eV (Cu 2p1/2) were detected in their Cu 2p XPS spectra, being assigned to both Cu0 and Cu+ species (indistinguishable); besides, a quite weak satellite peak at about 944.4 eV was also detectable (Fig. 7a), being ascribed to the cuprous oxide [49]. Although the Cu0 and Cu+ species were unable to be distinguished by XPS, two clear peaks at kinetic energy (K.E.) of 915.6 eV (Cu0) and 912.1 eV (Cu+) [50,51] could be detected in their Cu LMM Auger spectra (Fig. 7b). The ratio of Cu+ to Cu0 (Cu+/Cu0) on the surfaces of the reduced 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts was calculated to be 0.37 (x = 70), 0.43 (x = 80), and 0.65 (x = 90), using the corresponding peak areas deduced from the Auger spectra (Fig. 7b). Of interest is that the apparent reaction rate appears to be well-correlated with the Cu+/Cu0 ratio, suggesting that an optimal Cu+/Cu0 ratio is critical for achieving a high reaction rate (Fig. S5). Note that the reduced 15Cu/SiO2-80AE catalyst achieved an appropriate Cu+/Cu0 ratio close to 0.5, that might be the reason why the 15Cu/SiO2-80AE catalyst achieved the activity/selectivity for the dehydrogenation of MG to MGO reaction superior over the 15Cu/SiO2-70AE and -90AE catalysts (Fig. 2b). Not surprisingly, no any Cu+ species were detected on the surface of the reduced 15Cu/SiO2-IWI (Fig. S6, Table S2), being in line with its inertness in this reaction (Fig. 2a). On the basis of above results, we are confident that the Cu+/Cu0 pair showed synergistic catalysis for the dehydrogenation of MG to MGO reaction over a Cu/SiO2 catalyst. 3.5 Insight into the synergistic catalysis of Cu+/Cu0 pair It is plausible that the dehydrogenation of MG to MGO reaction catalyzed by our 15Cu/SiO2-xAE proceeded via an analogous mechanism previously reported for the dehydrogenation of ethyl lactate to ethyl pyruvate over a Cu-based catalyst [30]. In that case, the Cu+ was responsible for the O−H cleavage and subsequent α-C−H cleavage while the Cu0 served as the receptor of H atoms (from O−H and C−H cleaved on Cu+) and charged the bonding of them to form H2 [30]. To check this speculation, in-situ DRIFTS experiments on MG adsorption and desorption were performed to monitor the interaction with the Cu+/Cu0 pair. Fig. S7 shows the DRIFTS spectra of MG adsorption on the reduced 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts. After saturation adsorption of MG at 25 °C, a strong IR band appeared at ∼1754 cm−1, due to the vibration of CO bond in the ester group of the adsorbed MG molecule. Besides, the νs(O−H) and ν(C−H) vibrational bands of the adsorbed MG molecule were detected on all three 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts, evidenced by the broad band appeared at 3640–3050 cm−1 and the several sharp bands in range of 3020–2840 cm−1 [13]. Interestingly, the adsorption amount of MG on the 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts showed an upward trend with rising the AE temperature (x) from 70 to 90 °C, being in line with their Cu+/Cu0 ratio (Fig. 7b, Table S2). This observation indicated that the adsorption of MG molecule took place on the Cu+ species, being in good agreement with the report for the ethyl lactate (having an analogous molecule structure) adsorption on a Cu/SiO2 [30]. The DRIFTS spectra were then acquired by heating the 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts with adsorbed MG molecule in a N2 carrier gas, with the results shown in Fig. 8. On all three 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts, adsorbed MG molecule showed a quite similar desorption evolution against the temperature, which implied the interaction of MG with the Cu+/Cu0 pair. With rising the temperature, the νs(O−H) and ν(C−H) vibrational bands were weakened, indicating that the cleavage of the O−H and C−H bonds of the adsorbed MG proceeded on the Cu+/Cu0 pair to form CO. It is not surprising that the ν(CO) vibrational band stemmed from both aldehyde group and ester group showed a marked decline with rising the temperature, because dehydrogenation of MG to MGO as well as their desorption and leaving with N2 carrier gas became more and more favorable. Notably, the IR signals relevant to MG and MGO became almost undetectable at above 250 °C in case of the 15Cu/SiO2-70AE, reasonably due to the less Cu+ sites (Cu+/Cu0 ratio of only 0.37, Table S2) for MG adsorption (Fig. 8a). With the increase in the Cu+/Cu0 ratio, the adsorption strength of MG increases; notably, the vibrational IR bands disappear at 150 °C for the 15Cu/SiO2-80AE, whereas they could persist up to 250 °C for the 15Cu/SiO2-90AE (Fig. 8b,c, and Table S2). On the 15Cu/SiO2-80AE with a moderate Cu+/Cu0 ratio of 0.43 (Table S2), more MG was adsorbed than on the 15Cu/SiO2-70AE (Fig. S7) but the νs(O−H) and ν(C−H) vibrational bands disappeared at only 150 °C (Fig. 8a). On the 15Cu/SiO2-90AE with a high Cu+/Cu0 ratio of 0.65 (Table S2), the νs(O−H) vibrational band was still detected at 250 °C while the ν(C−H) bond even at 400 °C. In addition, MG-TPSR experiments were carried out to monitor the MG dehydrogenation over the 15Cu/SiO2-xAE catalysts, with the H2-MS signal evolutions also shown in Fig. 8d. As expected, the 15Cu/SiO2-80AE showed a H2-MS signal curve with a bigger slope in association with a lower initial temperature for H2 generation, in comparison with the 15Cu/SiO2-70AE and -90AE. The above results confirmed again the synergistic catalysis of Cu+/Cu0 pair in the catalytic dehydrogenation of MG to MGO reaction, that is, the O−H and α-C−H of MG molecule was stepwise cleaved on the Cu+ while formed H atoms were transferred onto Cu0 and bonded to form H2. This finding is in line with other study on the Cu/SiO2 catalysts for dimethyl oxalate (DMO) hydrogenation [38]. In that study [38], the yield of ethylene glycol reached its highest point when there was a Cu+/Cu0 ratio of 0.54, indicating that an appropriate Cu+/Cu0 ratio is responsible for high reaction activity. In accordance, it is easy to understand why the 15Cu/SiO2-80AE achieved superior catalytic performance for this reaction over the two others. In nature, this catalyst possessed an appropriate Cu+/Cu0 ratio (0.43) thereby leading to a good balance between the Cu+-mediated cleavage of O−H and α-C−H and Cu0-mediated reception and bonding of H atoms. Proposed reaction mechanism diagram is shown in Fig. S8. A too low Cu+/Cu0 ratio signified a poor adsorption capacity of MG while a too high Cu+/Cu0 ratio made Cu0 site not enough to take over and bond the H atoms in time. In other word, under such scenarios (for example, 15Cu/SiO2-70AE and -90AE) it is difficult to achieve optimal synergistic catalysis thereby showing an unsatisfying catalytic performance. 3.6 Deactivation and regeneration The catalyst stability, an important consideration for a heterogeneous catalyst in practical application, was tested in this reaction using the 15Cu/SiO2-80AE at 400 °C and a WHSV of 1.0 gMG gcat −1 h−1. As we can see from Fig. 9, the MG conversion and MGO selectivity both showed a fast decline within 10 h of running, dropping from 36.4 % and 78.1 to 21.5 % and 70.6 %. The reaction was then aborted and the spent catalyst was calcined in an air flow at 500 °C for 2 h and subsequently reduced in a H2 flow at 300 °C for 1 h. After that, second reaction test was performed to evaluate the catalyst regenerability. By air oxidation and subsequent H2 reduction, the spent catalyst could be fully recovered to its initial activity/selectivity level whereas it still experienced a similar fast deactivation within another 10 h of running. A third regeneration-reaction cycle was performed, showing a similarity of the conversion/selectivity evolution against the time on stream. To gain insight into the cause of catalyst deactivation, the used 15Cu/SiO2-80AE catalyst (i.e., that in Fig. 9) was characterized by XRD, TEM, AES, XPS, TGA, and DRIFTS, with the results shown in Figs. S9-S11. As we can see from Fig. S9a, a strong XRD pattern consisting of characteristic peaks for metallic Cu at 2θ of 43.2°, 50.4°, and 74.1° was detected (PDF #99–0034); the Cu particle was grown from 4.1 nm (freshly reduced, Table S2) to 4.7 nm after only 10 h reaction. The Cu particle size was also detected by TEM (Fig. S10) to be 4.7 nm for the used 15Cu/SiO2-80AE catalyst (being consistent to that (4.7 nm) by XRD measurement). Such slight growth of Cu paricles led to a slight decrease of the copper dispersion from 25.0 % to 21.3 % (Table S2). No Cu2+ species were detected by XPS on the surface of the used 15Cu/SiO2-80AE catalyst (Fig. S11), but the Auger spectrum in Fig. S9b showed that the Cu0 species were much more than the Cu+ species on the surface of such used catalyst while deducing a low Cu+/Cu0 ratio of 0.24 (almost a half of that (0.43, Table S2) before used). The above results indicated that slight sintering of Cu nanoparticles took place as well as the obvious reduction of Cu+ species. Moreover, severe coking also inevitably occurred on such catalyst, reaching a high coke amount of 7.9 wt% even after 10 h of running (Fig. S9c). In the DRIFTS spectra of the used catalyst (Fig. S9d), a series of bands were detected at 3750–3150 (O−H), 2962 (C−H), 1810–1700 (CO), and 1670–1560 (CC) cm−1, most likely due to the condensation of MG with MGO and aromatization [52–54]. In sum, rapid deactivation of such catalyst was caused by the reduction of Cu+ species, sintering of Cu nanoparticles, and ease of coking. Note that the spent catalysts could be recovered fully by air-oxidation and subsequent H2-reduction. 4 Conclusions The catalytic dehydrogenation of MG is an attractive route for the synthesis of MGO, but lack of qualified catalyst presents a grand challenge. Promising Cu/SiO2 catalysts have been developed for this reaction process, which are obtained by the ammonia evaporation method. The catalyst performance is found to be strongly dependent on their preparation and activation parameters as well as the reaction conditions, which is closely related to the Cu+/Cu0 ratio in the catalysts. The standout catalyst is the one with 15 wt% Cu loading, obtained by ammonia evaporation at 80 °C after calcining in air at 500 °C and subsequently reducing in H2 at 300 °C. Over this catalyst, a high MG conversion of 38.5 % is achieved with a MGO selectivity of 79.0 % at 400 °C and a WHSV of 1.0 gMG gcat −1 h−1. This catalyst achieves an optimal Cu+/Cu0 ratio of 0.43, which facilitates the balance between the Cu+-mediated cleavage of O−H and α-C−H and Cu0-mediated reception and bonding of H atoms. A Cu+/Cu0 ratio that is too low resulted in a diminished adsorption capacity for MG, while a ratio that is too high prevented the Cu0 site from effectively taking over and bonding of H atoms. Such catalyst is rapidly deactivated against the time on stream, which is mainly caused by the reduction of Cu+ species, Cu sintering, and coking. By air oxidation and subsequent H2 reduction, the catalytic performance of spent catalysts can be restored to its initial level. This study opens up new ways for the preparation of MGO while our findings will shed a light on rational design of more advanced catalysts for this reaction process. The Cu/SiO2-AE catalyst demonstrates potential in the dehydrogenation of MG to MGO. This catalytic approach adheres to green chemistry principles by eliminating the need for hazardous oxidants, thus offering a potentially environmentally friendly synthetic pathway for MGO production. Subsequent endeavors should concentrate on the development of low-temperature active/selective, coking-resistant catalysts for this reaction, with the objective of achieving a seamless transition to the large-scale production of MGO. coredata.dc:description: Dehydrogenation of methyl glycolate (MG) is an attractive method for synthesizing methyl glyoxylate (MGO, an important high-value chemical and pharmaceutical intermediate), which is calling for a qualified catalyst. Cu/SiO2-AE catalysts were prepared via the ammonia evaporation method for the title reaction, showing the catalytic performance strongly dependent on their preparation/activation parameters as well as the reaction conditions. The preferable 15Cu/SiO2-80AE (15 wt% Cu-loading; AE-treatment at 80 °C; calcined at 500 °C) after H2-reduction at 300 °C achieved a high MG conversion of 38.5 % with MGO selectivity of 79.0 % at 400 °C. The Cu/SiO₂-AE catalyst demonstrates promising catalytic performance, achieving 38.5 % MG conversion with 79.0 % MGO selectivity at 400 °C. The Cu⁺/Cu⁰ ratio plays a crucial role in catalytic activity, as revealed by XPS, FTIR, and MG-TPSR. Deactivation mechanisms were studied, and catalyst regeneration was explored, offering insights for industrial application in green MGO synthesis.
